captions.text: [MUSIC PLAYING]
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: It's impossible to
ignore the parallels between

being in the desert and
driving a race car.

The feeling of isolation, your
having total control over

every aspect of the experience,
and if something

goes wrong, there's nothing
there to save you.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: Inde Motorsports
Park is certainly remote

enough out in the
Arizona desert.

The front straight doubles as a
runway, so it's long, wide,
and unforgiving.

Rest of the two-mile
circuit is bumpy,
dusty, tight, and blind.

And the AVI Racing Corvette GT1
is probably the fastest
track car I've ever driven.

Or if not, it's certainly
the loudest.
In-car audio not, so much.

I have no idea if you can hear
me or not, this is by far the
loudest car I've ever driven.

AVI's Wayne McKeen, after
putting tens of thousands into

a C6 Corvette CO6 to go racing,
had a revelation--

if you want to build a Corvette
for the track, why

start with a Corvette that's
meant for the street.

That's like buying a
casino when all you
needed was a card table.

WAYNE MCKEEN: I love
Corvettes.

The geometry and the engineering
that's went into

the Corvette for a track
car is unbelievable.

And we needed a stiff chassis to
complement the geometry of
the Corvette.

This car is a tube-frame
GT1 Corvette race car.

Essentially, a Corvette stock
car, with a completely

rebuilt, redesigned
two-frame chassis
that's extremely stuff.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

WAYNE MCKEEN: The body of this
car is made out of--

this current car-- is made out
of fiberglass the production

cars will be out of carbon fiber
and Kevlar as an option,

which saves about 80 pounds
to the weight
of the whole vehicle.

And the chassis itself,
dry weight is about
23-30 the way it sits.

So, getting a stock zero 6 down
under 3,000 pounds for a
race car is extremely tough.

So we wanted to also widen the
track width of this car.

This car's eight inches wider
than a C6 Corvette.

So the track width and the
turn-in and everything is so
much better.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: Every bit of this
car is designed the way it is
for three specific reasons--

to be as fast as possible, as
light as possible, and as

simple as possible to fix,
because you go to the track to
drive, not to wrench.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

WAYNE MCKEEN: AVI Racing's
mission was to develop a race

car that was user-friendly,
extremely reliable, and easy
to work on.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: Removing the
complete carbon and fiberglass

body work takes two men only
six minutes, revealing a

skeleton that is more NASCAR
than Woodward Avenue.

A tube frame chassis with every
bit of racing technology

you would ever need
lurks underneath.

There's an adjustable brake bias
with two master cylinders

powering 14-inch
Brembo brakes.

There's a 28-gallon fuel cell,
beefed-up [INAUDIBLE]

suspension, and a triple-disc
clutch.

It has modular front and rear
frame components, which means

if you crash, you can replace
the entire front or rear

section for less than five
figures in your own garage.

Thanks to the ease of access,
one man can change a clutch or
transmission in under an hour.

There's ducting, cooling, tons
of down force, and massive

square-stance 305 section
slick tires.

WAYNE MCKEEN: Most people think
of a race car as a Rolex

or a World Challenge 253
$100,000 race car.

We wanted to develop a track
day car for $60,000--
a fraction of the money--
that will compete with those.

MATT FARAH: And Wayne should
know-- he benchmarked the GT1

against his LG Motorspots
World Challenge car.

And without the restrictions
World Challenge cars face, the
GT1 is faster--
much faster.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

WAYNE MCKEEN: We've taken our
years of race car experience

and developed an extremely fast,
reliable, affordable

race car that will compete
with the top cars
out in a track day.

It's extremely nimble, it tracks
really well, corners
extremely well.

It's so stiff that it corners
like no other car.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: Under the hood,
you won't just see a

505-horsepower LS3 engine, but
a complete C6 Corvette drive

line, including the cradles,
which is not only effective at

getting the power to the ground,
but also robust with

parts available in
nearly every city
in the United States.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

WAYNE MCKEEN: The driveline in
this car, as well as all the

suspension components, can be
bought at your local GM

Performance parts dealer,
including the transmission,

the diff, the engine itself
is all available at GM
Performance parts.
So it's very easy to--

if something happens or breaks,
to get new parts.

They're not custom, except
for the chassis itself.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: It's every bit as
exciting as it looks stepping
into this thing.

It's visceral to the
point of nirvana.

It's fast, grippy, responsive,
and has the best turn-in of
any car I've never driven.

It's wonderful, rewarding you
when you get it just right,

and kicking you in the ass
when you overcook it.

I stayed out, lap after lap,
pushing the car as hard as I

could, until I realized I was
having so much fun, I'd run
out of gas.

While it's important to
remember this car is a

prototype, the production cars
will be reaching customer

hands at the beginning
of next year.

And I can't wait to drive
one of those.

Now that we found out how well
it grips on the track, let's

see what happens when you
try and break it loose.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: I got
no gas pedal.
It's got no gas pedal here.

I somehow snapped the throttle
cable, and we didn't have time
to repair it, [INAUDIBLE]
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MATT FARAH: Though we came to
Indy to test the car, what we
got was an experience.

The people at AVI Racing are
true professionals who brought
us a great race car.

And because it's Arizona,
of course somebody
brought a Mac 10.
[GUN SHOT]

MATT FARAH: This is why like
shooting in Arizona--
the crew all brings guns.
[GUN SHOTS]

MATT FARAH: Is this thing
shooting huge flames out of
the barrel, or is it just me?
[GUN SHOTS]
MATT FARAH: Damn!
[GUN SHOTS]
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

MALE SPEAKER: Bleach on the
ground, soap on the tire.

MATT FARAH: Rental
minivan burn out.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

MALE SPEAKER: That worked
so good, doesn't it?

That's bleach and
soap combo, man.

title: The Ultra-Light, 505 WHP AVI Racing Corvette GT1 - /TUNED

comments.text: So basically its a race car that sort of looks like a corvette.﻿

comments.text:
That's a race car that makes sense. $60K, parts available anywhere, easy to 
take apart and reliable...except that fucking throttle cable LOL. I never

is as good as it gets for the fraction of the cost that any Benz, BMW or 
Audi would cost to buy, own and fix. Thumbs up﻿

the 15% average drain in a rwd vehicle.

+Quinten Verniers It's fiberglass and it's exactly how they come if you 
order one. You can choose to hav it wrapped or painted but that costs 
extra. The whole point is to have a super fast track car that won't break 
the bank. Considering that basically everything on these can be replaced at 
your local GM dealership that's what makes them exciting. Paint is what 
ricers worry about rather than performance.

comments.author: Russell Comer

comments.text:
+Russell Comer Haha, could have just been poor geometry on the throttle 
cable. Having it mounted slightly eskew can cause it to rub and eventually 
break. I've owned plenty of brand new cars that had things break within the 
first month of owning them. Just a fluke I'm sure.

comments.text: Must have been a Beta Cable.

a spare throttle cable.  Just because it snapped doesn't mean it's hard to 
fix.

comments.author: full press

comments.text:
+ModernProgram It has happened before, it's called the GT3 GTR. Two teams 
tried to use them, after half a season for one team, and almost a full for 
the other, they both dropped out. The chassis wasn't competitive to the 
Porsche, Ferrari, Viper, BMW, and Corvette competing teams. AWD doesn't 
belong on a race track, two much extra weight, and too much understeer.

comments.text:
+foolongtea But what if GTR was made the same way this car was. Meaning the 
exterior and interior materials?
comments.author: ModernProgram

for. But on a track, it would be no contest. The vette would mop the floor 
with an alpha.

comments.text:
.. Hows the compression dampening on your ride? seems a little high 
compared with your spring rate and roll-bar stiffness, and with the weight 
bias and tire widths of your car the front end is damped too low on rebound 
and compression, and the front sway bar is far too stiff...giving your ride 
a a really inconsistent front end with sporadic under-steer. however, once 
you get sideways you'll have yourself a pretty good lower-powered drift car 
for wet parking lots.

^ Agreed. Power:Weight is something many people forget about. Referring

comments.author: Project Garage

comments.text:
+Guus V,@Shadowboost; C6R actually weighs 2745lbs (as per corvette racing). 
C7R probably weighs about the same. BMW Z4 GTLM car: 2730lbs (as per BMW). 
Aston Martin GTE: 2711lbs (as per Aston Martin)... All weights are 
regulated now by IMSA. For Comparison to a Euro car in a Euro series, the 
BMW M4 DTM: ~2440lbs; AM GT3 ADAC series car: ~2600lbs; GTR GT3 ADAC: 
2900lbs, all as per ADAC. AVI racing corvette (at 2330lbs) isn't bad for a 
track car that you can actually buy and run flat out without too much 
worry. So it certainly isn't a bus. Body panels are fiberglass/carbon 
fiber; don't need interior. I also highly doubt it's a slow car; a factory 
C6 Z06 isn't slow and it has a couple hundred pounds on this car... so 
suggesting that this car is slow is just stupidity.
comments.author: clutchkickgoon

comments.text:
+Shadowboost I'm not trying to start anything here. But drive the car 
before you make statements like that. For reference, NASCAR racecars can 
weigh upwards of 3,000lbs, those are tube chassis with no interior as well. 
The C6R weighs 3353lbs (via corvetteracing.com), and the C6R does WELL.
comments.author: Project Garage

comments.text:
+kkgtyf With tube frame chassis and absolutely no interior?  Yeah, pretty

comments.author: Eric Holzman

comments.text:
Earlier in the comments a guy asked why they used a truck intake manifold 
on the engine. The Truck intake actually outflows all stock GM manifolds 
but the LS6, with this being a LS3 crate motor i'm betting they switched 
for the better low end torque, possibly to give better clearance for the 
drive accessories, or assuming the engine is lower in the car it would help 
raise the throttle body to help correct any issues. ﻿
comments.author: dudefromlaveenaz

comments.text:
The Vortec manifold does not out flow the LS1 ls3 or 7 manifolds.
It does provide the best torque under 4K rpm.
The truck manifold is Useless over 5,500 rpm.

comments.text:
Although a V6 would get more horsepower with a turbo or WHP, not 
necessarily. LS engines have to be one of the greatest engines ever built. 
Not the greatest but one of the greatest. An LSX engine can achieve 700 bhp 
stock with is about 650 or 600 WHP depending on the car's ability to 
transfer power to the wheels.
comments.author: exotic and domestic syndicate

comments.text:
+younginky  VG30DETT for starters and I'm sure there are more. 550-600whp 
are around the limit for the stock internals, a good tune is essential 
though. And a VR38DETT... probably 800+whp capable on stock internals if 
not more. RB26DETT and 2JZGTE can go that high as well, but those are I6.
comments.author: TheCarPassionChannel

comments.text:
+TheCarPassionChannel tell me one V6 engine you can 600hp from without 
rebuild it...
comments.author: younginky

comments.text:
+younginky  Not necessarily, some V6's are built very robust from the 
factory and can handle upwards of 600whp.
comments.author: TheCarPassionChannel

comments.text:
505whp is around 605 hp .... and for 600 hp in a v6 you need to rebuild the 
engine.
comments.author: younginky

comments.text:
More hp? Sure you can. Your taking that 6 cyl, lets say 3.3l and increasing 
its displacement via forced induction to 6.0l with out increasing its 
rotational mass. Then again, you turbo a ls motor and you can get gobs more 
hp as well.  The problem is there are very few racing classes for open 
class forced induction vehicles.  If you run a turbo or supercharger then 
you have to run some sort of restrictor on the inlet. Generally 32 to 
36mm.  Which means your turbo has lag like crazy, then runs out of breath 
above 5000 rpm.   A naturally aspirated engine is ideal for racing as it 
open you up to a great many classes to race in. And the LS platform is a 
proven, light weight powerful v8 that its extremely reliable.

comments.text: Please tell me that game actually exists...

comments.author: TheREALBennyChrist

comments.text:
+shyfxxf  Try to get a 500+whp 6 cylinder to keep up with that Corvette and 
be as reliable. Won't happen. I love turbo engines, in fact I'm even 
building one, but you can not argue the power and reliability and speed of 
a near-stock LS in a 2300lb chassis. +RsEramies you can definitely get 
500whp from a 6 cylinder without massive amounts of lag with the right 
setup, but definitely still wont be as fast around the track as a 500whp LS.
comments.author: TheCarPassionChannel
